content.description:
Start the climb on the rounded corner, or either side of it, and finish on the short face above. I started both left and right of the corner and found both sides felt a little harder than the 5.7 rating given by Swartling/Mayer.

 This is probably the same as the unnamed #9 in Swartling/Mayer.
content.location: Located on the rounded corner near the left side of the crag.

content.description:
What name do you give a route on a cracked up wall that Swartling/Mayer thought was interesting enough to list two unnamed routes, #6 and #7, both with the same enticing description "Crack system with several variations"?

 Climb this wall any way you want, across, up and down, or diagonal (maybe it should be called tic-tac-toe.) Staying as far right as possible seems about 5.5 as it is rated in S/M, but the crack on the left is much easier. One variation on top-rope to make it more interesting and longer is to traverse back and forth between the left crack and the right corner a few times.
content.location: Located on the right side of the left wall of the crag. Look for the face that is lined with multiple vertical and horizontal cracks.

content.description: The difficulty is at the bottom with no large cracks or edges to use. Part way up, the route opens up to much easier climbing on larger cracks and blocks.This is a named route in Swartling/Mayer.
content.location: Located on the right side of the ledge which is on the right side of the crag. It's the right-most climb listed by S/M at Crashing Rock Wall.

content.description: Climb the relatively smooth face up to the overhang. Climb over the overhang and finish on short face above.
content.protection: Setting up a toprope is a pain due to the slope and concentration of juniper branches.
content.location: Located near the middle of the left wall of the crag. It's the only real overhang you can climb at Crashing Rock.

content.description: Climb the crack up and angling slightly right past a small pine in the center of the wall.This is unnamed #2 in Swartling/Mayer.
content.location: Located in the middle of the ledge on the right side of the crag and a little right of the large pine growing from the ledge.

content.description: Smooth face below high point of buttress. Is the left arete on or not?!?!?
content.location: Starts on the lowest corner of buttress.

content.description: Un-named in the guide book this is a nice route to access the top ledge and set TR for "The Blackboard".
content.location: Around the corner west of The Blackboard.

content.description: Start on the ledge above and to the right of The Blackboard and climb up the cracks and blocks to a niche, then continue straight up to top.This is unnamed #3 in Swartling/Mayer.
content.location: On the right side of the crag. Located just left of the large pine tree growing from the left edge of the ledge.

content.description:
A short crack climb on the far left side of Crashing Rock wall. Perhaps the best thing about this climb is that it's the only one at Crashing Rock where you don't have to deal with juniper trees to set up a toprope.

 This is probably the same as the unnamed #10 in Swartling/Mayer.
content.location: Located on the farthest left side of the crag.

pathTokens: East Bluff 03 - West of the Quarry

content.description: A small chunk of rock with a distinctive, very smooth face: Â The Blackboard.
